chapter.title: Installation of Seam
chapter.para: Seam by nature requires Java 5. We also recommend to use the latest copy of JBoss in the CVS even though JBoss Seam would work in other application servers or even in a standalone Tomcat.

sect2.title: Java 5
sect2.para: First, install Java JDK 5.0 for your operating system, you can get it here

sect2.title: JBoss Head
sect2.para:
Now you will need to get jboss-head from CVS, compile it and setup JBOSS_HOME, to do so follow the following instructions:
Checkout the module jboss-head from the CVS repository of JBoss using :pserver:anonymous@anoncvs.forge.jboss.com:/cvsroot/jboss as CVSROOT. Typing cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@anoncvs.forge.jboss.com:/cvsroot/jboss co jboss-head will do it. Now that the module is checked out, go to the build directory and start build JBoss Head by starting build.bat or build.sh depending on which operating system you are using. To be able to build JBoss the first time, you will have to be connected to Internet. On some system, you may have a out of memory exception during the building, restart the build and it should finish the job. Make sure that typing "java -version" in a console returns a version 1.5 of Java, otherwise ejb3 libraries won't be compiled.
Now define the environment variable JBOSS_HOME to the full path leading to jboss-head/build/output/jboss-xxxxxx.

sect2.title: JBoss Seam
sect2.para:
Now you will need to get jboss-seam from CVS and compile it, to do so follow the following instructions:
Checkout the module jboss-seam from the CVS repository of JBoss using :pserver:anonymous@anoncvs.forge.jboss.com:/cvsroot/jboss as CVSROOT. Typing cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@anoncvs.forge.jboss.com:/cvsroot/jboss co jboss-seam will do it. Now that the module is checked out, go to the build directory and start build JBoss Seam by starting build.bat or build.sh depending on which operating system you are using.
Once this is all done, you should have a directory named seam.deployer inside $JBOSS_HEAD/server/default/deploy.
